div.p: idānīṃ cakrānām anukramaḥanukramaanukramā kathyatekathyaṃte/ Once again Rāmacandra presents descriptions of the cakras, but this time very brief covering merely the names and locations of each cakra. Given their detailled description in chapters 4 12 it seems redundant to mention them once again at this place. Either we could assume that Rāmacandra was a very thoughtless and unstructured author/compiler, or this phenomenon must be taken as a further indication that Rāmacandra had an educational intention for his audience and that this text was used as a textbook so that he immediately used the preceding verse to repeat the sequence of the cakra system that he already discussed in detail at the beginning of the text.ādhāreādhāro brahmacakrambrahmacakraṃ 1 // ādhāropariom. liṅgamūleliṅge svādhiṣṭhānacakramsvādhiṣṭhānacakraṃ 2 // nābhau maṇipūrakacakrammaṇipūrakacakraṃ 3 // hṛdaye 'nāhataanāhata°viśuddha°cakramcakraṃ 4 //[5] kaṇṭhasthāne viśuddhicakramanāhatacakraṃ 5 // ṣaṣṭhaṃṣaṣṭha° tālucakramtālucakraṃtālucakretālucakra 6 // bhruvor madhye ājñāagnejaāgneyaājñāyacakraṃcakram 7 // brahmarandhraom.sthāne kālabrahma°cakramcakraṃ 8 // navamam ānavamanavamaṃ rattunavamaṃkāśacakramcakraṃ 9 //[10] tat paetattataḥtatarama°paraṃpara°śūnyam°śūnyaṃtatparamaśūnyaṃ//

Now the sequence of the cakras is taught. At the supportIn the previous section on cakras Rāmacandra situates the first cakra, which he there calls mūlacakra, at the beginning (ādau) [of supposedly the central channel], which should be at the anus if we assume an ascending order, cf. p.. This assumption is further supported by the additional descriptions of U2 folio 2v. l.2 in which it is explicitly located at the anus (gudasthānam) and called ``ādhāracakra'' (``cakra of the support''). Thus, the location presented here as ādhāre (``at the support'') should be understood as mūlādhāre (``at the root support'')., there is the Brahmacakra. Above the support at the root of the gender is the Svadiṣṭhānacakra. At the navel, there is the Maṇipūrakacakra. In the heart [there is] the Anāhatacakra.[5] Situated within the throat is the Viśuddhicakra. The sixth is the Tālucakra. In the centre of the eyebrows is the Ājñācakra. At the opening of BrahmaThe brahmarandhrasthāne (``at the place of the aperture of Brahmā/Brahman'') is the fontanelle, through which the vital principle of the yogi exists at death, cf. rootsofyoga. is the KālacakraI have not been able to identify the term ``kālacakra'' (``cakra of time'') for the eighth cakra in other texts. All other texts that I am aware of designate the eighth cakra in a ninefold cakra system with different terms: peterson1888 4359/256.13 calls it nirvāṇa° (``absolute extinction''); shivayogapradipika 3.15 also designates it with nirvāṇa°; the ssplonavla 2.8 again calls it the nirvāṇacakraṃ; Yogasvarodaya as quoted in ramatosana (Ed. p. 833) only calls it aṣṭamaṃ cakraṃ (``the eighth cakra'') and siddhapuṃsaḥ sthalaṃ (``place of the accomplished human''); Rāmacandra himself in the previous chapter on cakras in 11.1 picks this up and calls it aṣṭamacakraṃ (``eighth cakra'') and siddhapuruṣasya sthānaṃ (``place of the accomplished person''); Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. ll. 2 3) calls it siddhapuruṣasyānacakraṃ (``the cakra of the accomplished person''); saubhagya again calls it nirvāṇacakram, but provides us with yet another unique designation parabrahmacakram (``cakra of the supreme Brahmā/Brahman''). The ninth is the ĀkāśacakraThe term ākāśacakra for the ninth cakra in the known ninefold cakra systems only occurs in shivayogapradipika 3.16 and ssplonavla 2.9.[10] It is supreme emptiness.

Now the divisions of the totalityI understand cakra here in the less common meaning of "troup, crowd, totality", cf. petersburger. of supports [for concentration] are taught. The first is the support at the big toe. From the execution of the fixation onto the light at the big toe of the feet stability of the gaze arises. The root support is the second [one]. The heel of the other foot is caused to be placed at the root of the big toe. As a result the fire is strengthened.[5] One heel is caused to be placed at the Root container. The heel of the other foot is caused to be placed at the root of the big toe of this foot. The fire of it is caused to be kindled. The third is the location of the anus spuport. From the execution of expansion and contraction a stable vitalwind arises.[10] And therefore death of the person does not arise.

The fourth is the penis support. Due to the execution of repeated practice of contracting the penis in the midst of therof, the adamantine channel appears in the middle of the staff of the backThe staff of the back (paścimadaṇḍa) is another name for the central channel.. From the repeated practice again [and again] the transition of both breath and mind into its center arises. Caused by the transition of both [breath and mind] into the center the trinity of knotsExplain the three knots. breaks. There, from the breaking of that, the vitalwind, after having filled up (the central channel?) resides within the Brahma lotusExplain the Brahma lotus. Is it the heart? or is it the final cakra?. From that virility and strength arise. The person becomes youthful forever. The fifth is Udyāna. From performing bandha there, urine and faeces disappear. The sixth is the support of the navel. From repeated practice of praṇava, the unstruck sound arises by itself.
